last_post.content:
Many scholars are leaving Twitter for #Mastodon, a public, decentralized alternative, impervious to private take-over:

https://www.science.org/content/article/musk-reshapes-twitter-academics-ponder-taking-flight

Scholarly organizations are already supporting this migration:

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-00486-3

and

https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.7643817

There are analogous solutions for another public good in private hands: journals. There are even levers the scholarly community could pull to incentivize an analogous migration:

https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5526634

What are we waiting for?

title: Don't believe ChatGPT - we do NOT offer a "phone lookup" service

last_post.content:
We wrote a blog post about our on-going nightmare: ChatGPT recommends us for a service we don't provide.

Dozens of people are signing up to our site every day and then getting frustrated when "it doesn't work". Hugely frustrating.

https://blog.opencagedata.com/post/dont-believe-chatgpt

Please do NOT trust the nonsense ChatGPT spits out.

Computers have been beating the best human Go players since 2016. The Go world champion retired in part because AI is “an entity that cannot be defeated.”

But a human just trounced one of the world’s best Go AIs 14 games to 1: https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/02/man-beats-machine-at-go-in-human-victory-over-ai

I think this news story is more interesting than it might first appear (without knowing details, so grain of salt). It isn’t just a gaming curiosity; it points to a fundamental flaw with “deep learning” approaches in general.
1/

last_post.content:
One thing that's being lost in a lot of the coverage related to Scott Adams' racist rant is that he tried to present (the 40-whatever percent of) black people (who participated in this poll) as being outrageous for objecting to that phrase "it's okay to be white."

And if it's a phrase you've never heard before, maybe you take it at face value and go, "Oh, so now they don't even think it's okay for white people to exist?!"

But it's deeper than that. 1/

title: GitHub - chainsawriot/rang: Reconstructing R computational environments

last_post.content:
Excited to introduce the #Rstats package rang (developed by @chainsawriot and me). The pkg helps to reconstruct historical R environments to make old code run again (ie make it reproducible!). So far, it supports all code back to R 2.1.0 (2005!)
https://github.com/chainsawriot/rang


The package is an Rchaeological tool to ensure reproducibility retrospectively. You can also use rang to make your current projects future proof, but pkgs like renv or groundhog are better suited for this task.

Twitter Blue: loved by Putin and the Taliban!

I've been testing @simon's amazing #Datasette tool, which makes it easy to explore CSV and JSON datasets: https://datasette.io

Simon has a version that runs in your (desktop) web browser, so I pointed it at my dataset.

Here's the link if you want to see for yourself:

https://lite.datasette.io/?json=https%3A%2F%2Fraw.githubusercontent.com%2Fanirvan%2F1940-singh-census%2Fmaster%2F1940_singh_census_basic.json#/data/1940_singh_census_basic?_filter_column_1=&_filter_op_1=exact&_filter_value_1=%5B%22non-South+Asian+wife%22%5D&_filter_column_2=&_filter_op_2=exact&_filter_value_2=Black&_filter_column=&_filter_op=exact&_filter_value=&_sort=rowid&_facet=gender&_facet=inferredGroups&_facet=raceRecordedNormalized&_facet=censusLocationNormalized&_facet=birthPlaceNormalized

I spent a few minutes exploring the facets, when I found three Black women with the last name of Singh in the 1940 U.S. Census (!!!)

This is the exact query I ran:

https://lite.datasette.io/?json=https%3A%2F%2Fraw.githubusercontent.com%2Fanirvan%2F1940-singh-census%2Fmaster%2F1940_singh_census_basic.json#/data/1940_singh_census_basic?_sort=rowid&_facet=gender&_facet=inferredGroups&_facet=raceRecordedNormalized&_facet=censusLocationNormalized&_facet=birthPlaceNormalized&raceRecordedNormalized=Black&inferredGroups=[%22non-South+Asian+wife%22

Why are so many people seeing more engagement on Mastodon than Twitter?

To me, the answer is pretty simple: Twitter tries to aggregate as much attention as possible around stuff that goes mega-viral.

There are only so many minutes in the day. So for stuff to "blow up big" necessitates that most of the rest of the posts from people we might actually want to hear from must go unseen.

Reminder to my PNW #rstats peeps! Submit your abstract for 2023 Cascadia R Conf! It’s a friendly bunch and we want to hear about the cool things you do with R.

I agree that a focus on product over process is often corrosive to learning,¹ but it seems that traditional grading regimes do more to promote this than generative AI. Also, it betrays a lack of imagination to suggest that these tools can’t put the focus on process.² Why aren’t the folks worrying about AI in education calling for a reassessment of assessment? That seems more inline w/ their stated goals. 🤔

____
¹ https://matthewbutterick.com/chron/camera-obscura-the-case-against-ai-in-classrooms.html h/t @dicthomson

² See e.g., https://findmycite.org

"Here’s where it’s important, yet again, to explain how #Section230 actually works. The fundamental point of Section 230 is to put the blame on the proper party: whoever is imbuing the content with whatever makes that content violate the law. That’s it.

@katestarbird We have controlled experiments showing half of the story:

Predictive text tools (e.g., most mobile keyboards) cause people to change content of what they write (word choices that are more "predictable" given the model used by predictive text and using fewer adjectives or other embellishments) compared to writing without predictive text.

http://www.eecs.harvard.edu/~kgajos/papers/2020/arnold20predictcive.shtml

title: TruthfulQA: Measuring How Models Mimic Human Falsehoods

last_post.content:
1/ Are larger #LLMs more truthful? A paper [1] from #ACL2022 tested up to #GPT3 and answered no.

[1] Stephanie Lin, Jacob Hilton, and Owain Evans. 2021. TruthfulQA: Measuring How Models Mimic Human Falsehoods. ACL 2022. https://arxiv.org/abs/2109.07958

#QA #GenerativeAI #NLP #NLProc #NLG #DeepLearning #Paper

New BIML Bibliography entry #MLsec

Lapuschkin, et al

Unmasking Clever Hans Predictors and Assessing What Machines Really Learn

This paper, though interesting, is limited to addressing only visual domains. Pixel relevance thus plays an outsize role in its treatment. A decent article to help counter ML hype, but not as strong as it could be.

See https://berryvilleiml.com/references/

title: Thank This World War II-Era Film Star for Your Wi-Fi

last_post.content:
Born in 1914, Hedy Lamarr was a famous American actress who pioneered the technology that would lead to WiFi, GPS, cell phones & Bluetooth communication.

Lamarr was brilliant. Among many fascinating inventions, she developed a new communication system with composer George Antheil that used “frequency hopping” among radio waves.

Once called the “most beautiful woman in the world," Lamarr is now remembered as "the mother of Wi-Fi."

https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smithsonian-institution/thank-world-war-ii-era-film-star-your-wi-fi-180971584/ #science #history #HistoryRemix

title: Pluralistic: Pluralistic is three (19 Feb 2023) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
"Both of these are bad choices, so I chose neither – or, depending on how you look at it, both. POSSE stands for "Post Own Site, Share Everywhere," and it's an idea that comes out of the Indieweb movement. Under POSSE, you post your work to a site you control, but syndicate to all the platforms and silos, with a link back to the original..."

title: Zombie newspaper sites, including Minneapolis' Southwest Journal, arise | MinnPost

last_post.content:
Thanks to #AI like #ChatGPT, welcome to “zombie #newspapers”:

“Minneapolis neighborhood newspaper the Southwest Journal shuttered at the end of 2020, but its web domain continues to post fresh content under the auspices of a Delaware ‘SEO company’ whose leader lives in Serbia.”

A few legacy articles under fictitious bylines still appear but recent posts are “junk content…to manipulate search engines.”

The new owner has “no interest in the #news business.”

#Journalism

https://www.minnpost.com/twin-cities-business/2023/02/zombie-newspaper-sites-including-minneapolis-southwest-journal-rise-from-grave/

title: Camera obscura: the case against AI in classrooms: Matthew Butterick

last_post.content:
I agree that a focus on product over process is often corrosive to learning,¹ but it seems that traditional grading regimes do more to promote this than generative AI. Also, it betrays a lack of imagination to suggest that these tools can’t put the focus on process.² Why aren’t the folks worrying about AI in education calling for a reassessment of assessment? That seems more inline w/ their stated goals. 🤔

____
¹ https://matthewbutterick.com/chron/camera-obscura-the-case-against-ai-in-classrooms.html h/t @dicthomson

² See e.g., https://findmycite.org

title: A dollar for your face: Meet the people behind Machine Learning models - AlgorithmWatch

last_post.content: Do you use a voice assistant? Do you like to add filters to your pictures? To make them, tech companies buy selfies and audio recordings from underpaid microworkers from poor countries like Venezuela or the Philippines. @algorithmwatch interviews #diplab researcher @ptubaro about the market for personal data that fuels AI. https://algorithmwatch.org/en/people-behind-machine-learning-models/

title: Dow said it was recycling our shoes. We found them in Indonesia

last_post.content: A Reuters journalist put 11 airtags in shoes destined to be recycled, but found they were being sold in used clothes markets instead ... okay, smart journalism ... but... isn't selling them just as good... or even better? I mean, if you have a used pair of shoes, the best thing for the environment is the prolong their use before they are cut up and recycled. So, I don't see what the problem is here. It might not be what was intended, but the outcome is surely better?!? https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/global-plastic-dow-shoes/

title: Physical attacks on power grid surge to new peak

last_post.content:
Attacks on the US power grid — a preferred method of attack among extremists, particularly accelerationists — have surged to a decade-high peak this year, with more than 100 attacks reported in the first 8 months of 2022. So that’s not even including the recent spate of attacks in NC, SC, FL, GA, WA, & OR.

These kinds of attacks are seen by extremists as a crucial step towards inciting a race war.
https://www.politico.com/news/2022/12/26/physical-attacks-electrical-grid-peak-00075216
